an7.68:1.1: “A mendicant with seven qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
an7.68:1.3: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, has self-knowledge, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows people high and low.
an7.68:2.1: And how is a mendicant one who knows the teachings?
an7.68:2.2: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings:
an7.68:2.3: statements, songs, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and classifications.
an7.68:2.4: If a mendicant did not know these teachings,
an7.68:2.5: they would not be called ‘one who knows the teachings’.
an7.68:2.6: But because they do know these teachings,
an7.68:2.7: they are called ‘one who knows the teachings’.
an7.68:2.8: Such is the one who knows the teachings.
an7.68:3.1: And how are they one who knows the meaning?
an7.68:3.2: It’s when a mendicant knows the meaning of this or that statement:
an7.68:3.3: ‘This is what that statement means; that is what this statement means.’
an7.68:3.4: If a mendicant did not know the meaning of this or that statement,
an7.68:3.5: they would not be called ‘one who knows the meaning’.
an7.68:3.6: But because they do know the meaning of this or that statement,
an7.68:3.7: they are called ‘one who knows the meaning’.
an7.68:3.8: Such is the one who knows the teachings and the one who knows the meaning.
an7.68:4.1: And how are they one who has self-knowledge?
an7.68:4.2: It’s when a mendicant has self-knowledge:
an7.68:4.3: ‘This is the extent of my faith, ethics, learning, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence.’
an7.68:4.4: If a mendicant did not have self-knowledge,
an7.68:4.5: they would not be called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.
an7.68:4.6: But because they do have self-knowledge,
an7.68:4.7: they are called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.
an7.68:4.8: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, and the one who has self-knowledge.
an7.68:5.1: And how are they one who knows moderation?
an7.68:5.2: It’s when a mendicant knows moderation when receiving robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an7.68:5.3: If a mendicant did not know moderation, they would not be called ‘one who knows moderation’.
an7.68:5.4: But because they do know moderation, they are called ‘one who knows moderation’.
an7.68:5.5: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, and the one who knows moderation.
an7.68:6.1: And how are they one who knows the right time?
an7.68:6.2: It’s when a mendicant knows the right time:
an7.68:6.3: ‘This is the time for recitation; this is the time for questioning; this is the time for meditation; this is the time for retreat.’
an7.68:6.4: If a mendicant did not know the right time,
an7.68:6.5: they would not be called ‘one who knows the right time’.
an7.68:6.6: But because they do know the right time,
an7.68:6.7: they are called ‘one who knows the right time’.
an7.68:6.8: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, the one who knows moderation, and the one who knows the right time.
an7.68:7.1: And how are they one who knows assemblies?
an7.68:7.2: It’s when a mendicant knows assemblies:
an7.68:7.3: ‘This is an assembly of aristocrats, of brahmins, of householders, or of ascetics.
an7.68:7.4: This one should be approached in this way. This is how to stand, to act, to sit, to speak, or to stay silent when there.’
an7.68:7.5: If a mendicant did not know assemblies,
an7.68:7.7: they would not be called ‘one who knows assemblies’.
an7.68:7.8: But because they do know assemblies,
an7.68:7.10: they are called ‘one who knows assemblies’.
an7.68:7.11: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, the one who knows moderation, the one who knows the right time, and the one who knows assemblies.
an7.68:8.1: And how are they one who knows people high and low?
an7.68:8.2: It’s when a mendicant understands people in terms of pairs.
an7.68:8.4: one likes to see the noble ones, one does not.
an7.68:8.5: The person who doesn’t like to see the noble ones
an7.68:8.7: The person who does like to see the noble ones
an7.68:9.1: Two people like to see the noble ones:
an7.68:9.2: one likes to hear the true teaching, one does not.
an7.68:9.3: The person who doesn’t like to hear the true teaching
an7.68:9.5: The person who does like to hear the true teaching
an7.68:10.1: Two people like to hear the true teaching:
an7.68:10.2: one lends an ear to the teaching, one does not.
an7.68:10.3: The person who doesn’t lend an ear to the teaching
an7.68:10.5: The person who does lend an ear to the teaching
an7.68:11.1: Two people lend an ear to the teaching:
an7.68:11.2: one remembers the teaching they’ve heard, one does not.
an7.68:11.3: The person who doesn’t remember the teaching they’ve heard
an7.68:11.5: The person who does remember the teaching they’ve heard
an7.68:12.1: Two people remember the teaching they’ve heard:
an7.68:12.2: one reflects on the meaning of the teachings they have remembered, one does not.
an7.68:12.3: The person who does not reflect on the meaning of the teachings they have remembered
an7.68:12.5: The person who does reflect on the meaning of the teachings they have remembered
an7.68:13.1: Two people reflect on the meaning of the teachings they have remembered:
an7.68:13.2: one understands the meaning and the teaching and practices accordingly, one understands the meaning and the teaching but does not practice accordingly.
an7.68:13.3: The person who understands the meaning and the teaching but does not practice accordingly
an7.68:13.5: The person who understands the meaning and the teaching and practices accordingly
an7.68:14.1: Two people understand the meaning and the teaching and practice accordingly:
an7.68:14.2: one practices to benefit themselves but not others, and one practices to benefit both themselves and others.
an7.68:14.3: The person who practices to benefit themselves but not others
an7.68:14.5: The person who practices to benefit both themselves and others
an7.68:15.1: That’s how a mendicant understands people in terms of pairs.
an7.68:16.1: That’s how a mendicant is one who knows people high and low.
an7.68:16.2: A mendicant with these seven factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
